snippet.textDisplay:
There is a huge problem at 28:25
What will happen when we import so many 3d assets that already have been completed either with the older versions of corona or vray and we use the new corona converter?
It will just produce such mayhem since Corona 7 will convert the materials into physical materials and a lot of times that will be plain wrong. I expected an issue when used the converter on a bed model and all the fabrics were converted into metallic materials so i had to go one by one material and reset the material back to default. 
Could you elaborate a little more on this subject?

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi! YouTube comments are not read by developers or support, so the best place to engage in conversation about this is over on the forums. There is even a specific thread for discussing the converter at https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php?topic=33253.0

As a quick note, there are always going to be some issues, because some older materials would be "physically impossible" so converting them into a "physically probable" is never going to be 100%. But for those, if it's vital they look the same using the impossible material, they can be kept as the Legacy material. Thanks! Tom
snippet.textOriginal:

But for those, if it's vital they look the same using the impossible material, they can be kept as the Legacy material. Thanks! Tom

snippet.textDisplay: @3D Stüdyo Scenes would need to be created in and saved from the older version - there are often other things that change, not just materials but things like the any UHD / 4K Cache files, render settings, etc. So it would be a choice on whether to create a scene using the latest version and features and offer that, or create a scene using older features (which users of new versions can convert to the new version). As a note, you can install more than one version of Corona at once, making it possible to use, say, Corona 7 for your scenes and renders for clients, but Corona 6 for scenes you intend to sell, etc. Hope that helps! Tom
snippet.textOriginal: @3D Stüdyo Scenes would need to be created in and saved from the older version - there are often other things that change, not just materials but things like the any UHD / 4K Cache files, render settings, etc. So it would be a choice on whether to create a scene using the latest version and features and offer that, or create a scene using older features (which users of new versions can convert to the new version). As a note, you can install more than one version of Corona at once, making it possible to use, say, Corona 7 for your scenes and renders for clients, but Corona 6 for scenes you intend to sell, etc. Hope that helps! Tom

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi! No, that's not possible, sorry. While we work on compatibility where a new version can load and use what is present from an old version, the opposite is not possible (because the old version had no idea what the new features would be in the next version to have compatibility built in... we'd need a time machine :) ).

As for the materials, the Legacy Material (Corona 6 material) is only there to render old scenes, and is not recommended for any new scenes. Since it's legacy / deprecated, and should not be used, there's no way to convert back to it, or to save to the old version (as there is no reason to do so, the new material is better all round). Thanks! Tom
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi! No, that's not possible, sorry. While we work on compatibility where a new version can load and use what is present from an old version, the opposite is not possible (because the old version had no idea what the new features would be in the next version to have compatibility built in... we'd need a time machine :) ).

As for the materials, the Legacy Material (Corona 6 material) is only there to render old scenes, and is not recommended for any new scenes. Since it's legacy / deprecated, and should not be used, there's no way to convert back to it, or to save to the old version (as there is no reason to do so, the new material is better all round). Thanks! Tom

snippet.textDisplay: Hi guys. So I was wondering what happened to the reflection slot. Where can I plug in the reflection maps on the new physical material
snippet.textOriginal: Hi guys. So I was wondering what happened to the reflection slot. Where can I plug in the reflection maps on the new physical material

snippet.textDisplay:
That is a good question! So with the new Physical Material the idea is that you're creating materials in a more physically correct way and arbitrarily putting in a map to control the reflection intensity is ... Not so correct.

To that end you can achieve similar control in a more physically correct way by plugging in the proper roughness / glossiness map where you can control how "diffuse" certain parts of the material are - and if they are really diffuse then the reflections will look dimmer.

That said if you want to use reflection maps with the Specular workflow in mind then going under the "Advanced" tab in the new Physical Material and selecting "Disney Specular" in there might be what you want.

In any case we'd suggest hopping over to our forums (https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php) where you can open up a thread and we can discuss things in even more detail.
Nejc
snippet.textOriginal:
That is a good question! So with the new Physical Material the idea is that you're creating materials in a more physically correct way and arbitrarily putting in a map to control the reflection intensity is ... Not so correct.

To that end you can achieve similar control in a more physically correct way by plugging in the proper roughness / glossiness map where you can control how "diffuse" certain parts of the material are - and if they are really diffuse then the reflections will look dimmer.

That said if you want to use reflection maps with the Specular workflow in mind then going under the "Advanced" tab in the new Physical Material and selecting "Disney Specular" in there might be what you want.

In any case we'd suggest hopping over to our forums (https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php) where you can open up a thread and we can discuss things in even more detail.
Nejc

snippet.textDisplay: I just finished an on-line course on Corona and 3DS Max, but it only used the legacy Corona materials, and now I am completely lost on how to interpret the differences …and how to convert them (the Corona converter doesn't always convert accurately). This video touches on the differences, but is it possible to make one that focuses on how to convert our old legacy materials accurately into the new Physical ones? (e.g. what is the new equivalent of Refl. gloss?)
snippet.textOriginal: I just finished an on-line course on Corona and 3DS Max, but it only used the legacy Corona materials, and now I am completely lost on how to interpret the differences …and how to convert them (the Corona converter doesn't always convert accurately). This video touches on the differences, but is it possible to make one that focuses on how to convert our old legacy materials accurately into the new Physical ones? (e.g. what is the new equivalent of Refl. gloss?)

snippet.textDisplay: Reflection glossiness is the same (if you swap to Glossiness mode, which can be done per material, or as a default for all scenes). Or you can use Roughness (you can swap between them by inverting a bitmap, but it's easier to use the bitmap in its original form and just choose whether it's Glossiness or Roughness in the material)
snippet.textOriginal: Reflection glossiness is the same (if you swap to Glossiness mode, which can be done per material, or as a default for all scenes). Or you can use Roughness (you can swap between them by inverting a bitmap, but it's easier to use the bitmap in its original form and just choose whether it's Glossiness or Roughness in the material)

snippet.textDisplay: Hi! We will do our best to have several videos on the Physical Material, but those will come over time. Meantime, check the helpdesk where there are shorter, more specific videos that may help, and you can always post over on the forums too for help in specific cases (do note that if a material was not physically realistic in any other material, including the Legacy, it may be impossible to tell how it should be converted automatically to the Physical Material, so automatic conversion may not always be possible). https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php?topic=33253.0 would be the thread for conversion questions, issues, etc. Thanks! Tom
snippet.textOriginal: Hi! We will do our best to have several videos on the Physical Material, but those will come over time. Meantime, check the helpdesk where there are shorter, more specific videos that may help, and you can always post over on the forums too for help in specific cases (do note that if a material was not physically realistic in any other material, including the Legacy, it may be impossible to tell how it should be converted automatically to the Physical Material, so automatic conversion may not always be possible). https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php?topic=33253.0 would be the thread for conversion questions, issues, etc. Thanks! Head to the forums though, where such things are possible, and we and the community at large will be happy to help! https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php Thanks! Tom

snippet.textDisplay:
Wait.. Please correct me if I'm wrong. Clear coat is for the most part refractive and doesn't really absorb much of color. It's actually the coats underneath, that absorb specific light waves and define a color. That's what I remember, how these things were thought in physics class?
So adding the absorbed color into the clearcoat section, doesn't make any sense to me from the physical correctness point of view? Or is this meant for colored metals or something like this, because they have colored reflection...thanks in advance for your answers.
snippet.textOriginal:
Wait.. Please correct me if I'm wrong. Clear coat is for the most part refractive and doesn't really absorb much of color. It's actually the coats underneath, that absorb specific light waves and define a color. That's what I remember, how these things were thought in physics class?
So adding the absorbed color into the clearcoat section, doesn't make any sense to me from the physical correctness point of view? Or is this meant for colored metals or something like this, because they have colored reflection...thanks in advance for your answers.

snippet.textDisplay: @foshizzlfizzl Ah just an industry standard name so we'' stay with it - but you are correct, since the coat does not have to be clear at all! Thanks! Tom
snippet.textOriginal: @foshizzlfizzl Ah just an industry standard name so we'' stay with it - but you are correct, since the coat does not have to be clear at all! Thanks! Tom

snippet.textDisplay:
@CoronaRenderer Hi Tom
Thanks for your explanation! That example with varnish makes sense now... But then the chosen name clear coat is missleading and confusing to me. Maybe coat would make more sense, but that's up to you ;)
snippet.textOriginal:
@CoronaRenderer Hi Tom
Thanks for your explanation! That example with varnish makes sense now... But then the chosen name clear coat is missleading and confusing to me. Maybe coat would make more sense, but that's up to you ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
Clearcoat is like a layer of extra material painted over a surface - just like a varnish. And just like a varnish, that can indeed have absorption, e.g. a dark brown all the way through to crystal clear, depending on the material being used as the coat. If you paint over a light wood with a heavy dark brown varnish, then all aspects of the light wood (its diffuse and its reflection etc) will become colored by how the top layer absorbs light - which is what happens here.

Clearcoat is not required for colored metals, anything set to Metal has its color controls (non-Metals always reflect white, so there are no color controls for reflection there... unless you add a clearcoat on top, again like the wood, the reflection of light there would be white, unless that is passing through a colored varnish).

Thanks!
  Tom
snippet.textOriginal:
Clearcoat is like a layer of extra material painted over a surface - just like a varnish. And just like a varnish, that can indeed have absorption, e.g. a dark brown all the way through to crystal clear, depending on the material being used as the coat. If you paint over a light wood with a heavy dark brown varnish, then all aspects of the light wood (its diffuse and its reflection etc) will become colored by how the top layer absorbs light - which is what happens here.

Clearcoat is not required for colored metals, anything set to Metal has its color controls (non-Metals always reflect white, so there are no color controls for reflection there... unless you add a clearcoat on top, again like the wood, the reflection of light there would be white, unless that is passing through a colored varnish).

Thanks!
  Tom

snippet.textDisplay: I downloaded corona 7 and it came with 3.4 GB of material and I don't know how to use it?
snippet.textOriginal: I downloaded corona 7 and it came with 3.4 GB of material and I don't know how to use it?

snippet.textDisplay:
Howdy! If you are a Cinema 4D user then it's accessible by selecting the "Material Library" under the "Corona" menu at the top. If you're confused about where the "Corona" menu is, it's in the same menu line as is "File" or "Edit" :)

If you are a 3ds Max user then you can access the library by bringing up the "Render Setup" window go under the "Scene" compartment and in there you'll see a button to open up the Material Library.

In both DCCs once you have the Material Library open you just click and drag those materials onto your objects / your material editors.

Hope that helps!
Nejc
snippet.textOriginal:
Howdy! If you are a Cinema 4D user then it's accessible by selecting the "Material Library" under the "Corona" menu at the top. If you're confused about where the "Corona" menu is, it's in the same menu line as is "File" or "Edit" :)

If you are a 3ds Max user then you can access the library by bringing up the "Render Setup" window go under the "Scene" compartment and in there you'll see a button to open up the Material Library.

In both DCCs once you have the Material Library open you just click and drag those materials onto your objects / your material editors.

Hope that helps!
Nejc

snippet.textOriginal: To be fair the corona converter is just useless. Its easier to redo the material. I think its better if you remove it completely. 9 materials from 10 has metallic workflow, lol? I understand that its not accurate, but when you have a wood with an ior of 2.2 it doesn’t mean its metal…so yea corona 6 converter was a huge time saver, this is useless.

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry to hear you don't find it helpful :( For us to improve it, we'd need to see examples of the materials that don't convert well (bear in mind that some materials CAN'T convert well, if they broke physical laws in how they were set up, which was possible in the Legacy material) - to share examples, head on over to the forums where images, scenes, etc. can be shared and support and developers can see it. https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php?topic=33253.0 - thanks! Tom
snippet.textOriginal: Sorry to hear you don't find it helpful :( For us to improve it, we'd need to see examples of the materials that don't convert well (bear in mind that some materials CAN'T convert well, if they broke physical laws in how they were set up, which was possible in the Legacy material) - to share examples, head on over to the forums where images, scenes, etc. can be shared and support and developers can see it. https://forum.corona-renderer.com/index.php?topic=33253.0 - thanks! Tom

snippet.textDisplay: I was wondering can you just change the name of the renderer brings sad memories
snippet.textOriginal: I was wondering can you just change the name of the renderer brings sad memories

snippet.textDisplay: @CoronaRenderer thats true i guess but what's halo and sun though
snippet.textOriginal: @CoronaRenderer thats true i guess but what's halo and sun though

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry for the sad memories. Apologies, we can't change the name of the engine, as it is already established under this name, and had the name long before the pandemic - the word also has many other meanings, such as the halo around the sun, so does not just have to bring to mind the recent situation. Best regards, Tom
snippet.textOriginal: Sorry for the sad memories.
